channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: The Taliban's favorite sport is...
item.description: He plays the only sport approved by the Taliban. Now Mohammad Nabi Eisakhil hopes the game he learned as a refugee will help unite his country. "This is a game that can bring Afghanistan together," he says.

item.title: Watch evolution of the cell phone
item.description: CNN's Jim Boulden looks back to the first mobile phone call made 40 years ago.

item.title: Two convicted of plot to kill Joss Stone
item.description: Two men who police said were arrested with Samurai swords outside the home of British singer-songwriter Joss Stone in 2011 were found guilty in an English court Wednesday of plotting to murder and rob her.

item.title: 36 reasons citizen journalism matters
item.description: The Internet can get pretty overwhelming sometimes. If you're like me, there are days when it feels like you can't stay on top of the endless stream of media. It seems impossible to discover the best content in all that noise.

item.title: Report: Saudis order man paralyzed
item.description: Rights group Amnesty International has condemned a reported Saudi court ruling sentencing a man to be paralyzed as retribution for having paralyzed another man as "outrageous."

item.title: Ex-player: Bullying coaches are norm
item.description: Too often, it's tempting to view sports through rose-tinted glasses. We believe that coaches always have the best interests of our young people at heart and that everything they do on the side of that court, field, pool or track is for the long-term, holistic benefit of young people.

item.title: Media: Stop crowning Hillary Clinton
item.description: Hillary Clinton is front-page news again. What did she do to warrant this treatment?

item.title: U.S. on Korea tension: This does not need to get hotter
item.description: Missile and launch components have been moved to the east coast of North Korea, a U.S. official with direct knowledge of the information tells CNN.

item.title: N. Korea: 'Moment of explosion' nears
item.description: North Korea stirs up fresh unease, threatening attacks by a "smaller, lighter and diversified" nuclear force, as the U.S. says it is sending a missile defense system to Guam.

item.title: U.S. military moves near North Korea
item.description: Amidst North Korea's ongoing verbal salvos, the United States has made a show of military strength in the annual drills taking place in the Korean Peninsula.

item.title: N. Korean social media appears hacked
item.description: Some official North Korean Internet and social media sites appeared Thursday to have been hacked, possibly by the hacker collective Anonymous.

item.title: Why Kim Jong Un isn't crazy
item.description: March brought us a series of what pundits like to call "provocations" by North Korea. On closer inspection, Pyongyang has opted for rhetoric over actual military actions.

item.title: U.S. state bans scores of gun types
item.description: Saying he hopes it sets an example for the nation, Connecticut Gov. Dannel Malloy on Thursday signed what advocacy groups call the strongest and most comprehensive gun legislation in the nation.

item.title: Nine dead in India building collapse
item.description: At least nine people were killed Thursday evening and more than 40 were injured when a building collapsed in India, sources told CNN sister network CNN-IBN.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius 'not officially training'
item.description: South African sprinter Oscar Pistorius is "not back on any official training program," his uncle said Thursday, rejecting media reports that the Olympic and Paralympic athlete accused of murder in his girlfriend's February shooting death was preparing to race again.

item.title: China's bird-flu death toll up to five
item.description: A fourth person in China has died from the H7N9 virus, a strain of avian flu not previously detected in humans, state-run TV reported Thursday.

item.title: France debates same-sex marriage bill
item.description: The French Senate will debate a controversial bill Thursday that would extend the right to marry and adopt to same-sex couples.

item.title: Report: Palestinian dies after clashes
item.description: A second Palestinian man died Thursday from injuries he suffered during clashes with Israeli security forces a day earlier, the official Palestinian news agency said.

item.title: Did Israel deny man medical care?
item.description: Violence erupts in the Palestinian territories following the death of a Palestinian prisoner from cancer.

item.title: Dozens die in Argentina storm
item.description: Heavy rains in Argentina have claimed at least 35 lives in the city of La Plata, outside Buenos Aires, officials said Wednesday.

item.title: 'Finding Nemo' gets a sequel
item.description: "Finding Nemo" gets a sequel, Stanley Tucci on picking his roles, Wynonna Judd hangs up her dancing shoes.

item.title: Bubba Watson's $40K hovercraft
item.description: Bubba's golf cart hovercraft will cost you $40,000. CNN's Jeanne Moos has the story behind Bubba's new "driver."

item.title: Marseille sorry for Barton's Twitter rant
item.description: Not for the first time Joey Barton is in trouble.

item.title: F1: Red Bull clock quickest pit stop
item.description: Red Bull have left all other Formula One teams trailing in their wake in recent years, and now it would seem the reigning drivers' and constructors' champions are also the quickest in the pit lane.

item.title: Armstrong swim contest sunk
item.description: Even at the age of 41 Lance Armstrong's thirst for competition remains undimmed.

item.title: UAB Chief: Gulf States will tax eventually
item.description: Tax-free Gulf States will eventually be a thing of the past, according to the head of the Union of Arab Banks.

item.title: How Korean war might play out
item.description: CNN's Tom Foreman and retired General James Marks map out potential strategies if North Korea attacks South Korea.

item.title: Wearable tech tracks your life
item.description: CNN takes a look at the future of interactive technology.

item.title: The evolution of the cell phone
item.description: CNN's Jim Boulden looks back to the first mobile phone call made 40 years ago.

item.title: Olympic swimmer goes for TV gold
item.description: Anderson Cooper has a preview of Ryan Lochte's upcoming E! reality TV show.

item.title: Are models getting thinner?
item.description: Former fashion editor Kirstie Clements reveals secrets on what models do to stay thin.

item.title: Distraction: Cat walks dog
item.description: Everything is wrong about this. The natural order of things has been disrupted. Run for the hills!

item.title: Behind the scenes at Paris St Germain
item.description: CNN's Pedro Pinto goes behind the scenes at Paris St Germain -- the Champions League contenders who held the mighty Barcelona.

item.title: Top scientist aims to 'repair the brain'
item.description: Ed Boyden is only 33, but he's already helped invent influential technologies in the study of the human brain.

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg's first website?
item.description: A blinking dinosaur eye. A nod to Eminem. A crude effort at connecting friends and "friends of friends." Were these the awkward first steps toward a multibillion-dollar social media empire?

item.title: Jesse Jackson: What MLK would fight now
item.description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson: Today is the 45th anniversary of the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

item.title: 'Dark matter' clues detected in space
item.description: Nearly two years after it was sent up to the International Space Station, a giant particle physics detector has provided its first results in the search for the mysterious "dark matter" believed to be a major component of the universe.

item.title: Film critic Roger Ebert dies at age 70
item.description: Legendary film critic Roger Ebert, who this week said he was facing a recurrence of cancer, has died at 70, according to the Chicago Sun-Times, which syndicated his column.

item.title: New breakthough for AIDS vaccine?
item.description: Researchers report a breakthrough in generating powerful antibodies that can neutralize HIV.

item.title: Who's next to legalize same-sex marriage?
item.description: It's not just the U.S. grappling with the issue of same-sex marriage. Many countries around the world appear to be on the brink of big changes.

item.title: Would you like death with your sport?
item.description: How do you like your sport? Blood, sweat, tears and a nailbiting finish, no doubt. But what about death?

item.title: 'Hallelujah moment' behind Post-it note
item.description: It's been described as the solution to a problem nobody realized existed.

item.title: "Finding Nemo" gets a sequel
item.description: "Finding Nemo" gets a sequel, Stanley Tucci on picking his roles, Wynonna Judd hangs up her dancing shoes.

item.title: Youth: Straight, LBGT or 'other'?
item.description: Are younger people more likely to embrace their sexual identity -- or even create their own category?

item.title: 12 women who changed business
item.description: 12 women entrepreneurs of the last century

item.title: Homeless kids to incredible acrobats
item.description: In Zambia, thousands of children live on the streets, many affected by HIV. But Barefeet Theatre is a group of former street children that uses performing arts to educate homeless children in Zambia and help keep them off the streets.

item.title: Are models getting even thinner?
item.description: Former fashion editor Kirstie Clements reveals secrets on what models do to stay thin.

item.title: Basketball coach abuses players
item.description: Rutgers fired head basketball coach Mike Rice after video surfaced of him shoving and berating players.

item.title: Egypt fury over Jon Stewart flap
item.description: A lesson for Mohamed Morsy: If you interrogate Egypt's answer to U.S. comedian Jon Stewart, you may end up facing the wrath of the real Jon Stewart.

item.title: What's changed since Marikana?
item.description: A survivor of last year's Marikana massacre in South Africa is still haunted by the police shootings.

item.title: Scandal strikes Spain's royal family
item.description: Spain's Princess Cristina summoned to court in corruption inquiry. CNN's Al Goodman reports.

item.title: Sex appeal trumps glamor in the air?
item.description: CNN's Richard Quest talks to a former Pan Am stewardess, Christel Vane, about the bygone era of airline glamour.

item.title: Happy birthday: Cellphone turns 40
item.description: Auto-correct and "Angry Birds." GPS, and those awkward texts from last night.

item.title: McIlroy: I know what I'm doing
item.description: Rory McIlroy says he's not listening to any of his critics in the build up to the Masters as the world No. 2 reflected on his troubled start to 2013.

item.title: The Taliban's favorite sport is...
item.description: He plays the only sport approved by the Taliban. Now Mohammad Nabi Eisakhil hopes the game he learned as a refugee will help unite his country. "This is a game that can bring Afghanistan together," he says.

item.title: Ware: 'Never want to see the video'
item.description: University of Louisville guard Kevin Ware doesn't want to see any replays of his severely broken leg, suffered during a weekend basketball game on national television, he told CNN Wednesday.

item.title: Ban the killer robots now
item.description: As wars become increasingly automated, we must ask ourselves how far we want to delegate responsibility to machines. Where do we want to draw the line?

item.title: iReport Awards: 36 stories that matter
item.description: The Internet can get pretty overwhelming sometimes. If you're like me, there are days when it feels like you can't stay on top of the endless stream of media. It seems impossible to discover the best content in all that noise.

item.title: From prison cell to football field
item.description: Brian Banks wore the uniform of a prison inmate for more than five years, serving time for a rape he didn't commit.

item.title: 'Good Jew' hashtag sparks lawsuit
item.description: France's Union of Jewish Students brought legal action against Twitter, CNN's Atika Shubert reports form London.

item.title: Wearable tech tracks your life
item.description: CNN takes a look at the future of interactive technology.

item.title: Why ideas festivals are 'brain viagra'
item.description: It's a windy and misty Sunday afternoon in March in the beautiful coastal town of Aldeburgh, Suffolk, and bleary-eyed travelers are disembarking from a coach after a two-hour journey from London.

item.title: Race starts to replace Hugo Chavez
item.description: The acting president of Venezuela and the opposition kick off an abbreviated campaign. CNN's Rafael Romo reports.

item.title: My brother tried to kill me -- for 'honor'
item.description: Afghani teenager Gul Meena is the victim of an attempted murder... by her own brother. He attacked her after saying she was immodest.

item.title: Why North Korea is far from suicidal
item.description: The North Korean regime has been issuing a barrage of threats against its neighbor for decades. Korean expert Sung-Yoon Lee says its strategy is to instill fear and hysteria and is neither crazy or suicidal.

item.title: Is U.S. escalating N. Korea tension?
item.description: Amid threats of a North Korean attack, the U.S. says it is deploying defensive missiles to Guam. But some fear the response could contribute to escalating tensions. CNN's Pentagon correspondent Barbara Starr explains.

item.title: North Korea
item.description: North Korea, which today accused the U.S. of pushing the region to the "brink of war," could be planning a missile launch soon, according to one U.S. official.

item.title: 'Dark matter' clues
item.description: Nearly two years after it was sent up to the International Space Station, a giant particle physics detector has provided its first results in the search for the mysterious "dark matter" believed to be a major component of the universe.

item.title: Same-sex marriage
item.description: It's not just the U.S. grappling with the issue of same-sex marriage. Many countries around the world appear to be on the brink of big changes.

item.title: Models thinner?
item.description: Former fashion editor Kirstie Clements reveals secrets on what models do to stay thin.

item.title: Killer robots
item.description: As wars become increasingly automated, we must ask ourselves how far we want to delegate responsibility to machines. Where do we want to draw the line?

item.title: Reef's beauty captured on film
item.description: Doing for our oceans what Google Street View has done on land, a team of marine scientists is building up an extraordinary picture of the world's coral reefs.

item.title: Oceans on brink of collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, the remaining wildernesses on our planet have retreated. However, dive just a few meters below the ocean surface and you will enter a world where humans very rarely venture.

item.title: Our Oceans: Victim or savior?
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: Modeling Earth's ecosystems
item.description: A group of researchers is building a comprehensive model of the Earth's ecosystems to help predict climate change.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: 'Iron Man 3' remixed for China
item.description: "Iron Man 3" and other Hollywood films are being altered to appeal to Chinese audiences.

item.title: Apple CEO apologizes to China
item.description: Apple has published a letter to Chinese customers -- signed by CEO Tim Cook -- that addresses the growing controversy over the company's warranty policies there.

item.title: 2 dead from unusual bird flu strain
item.description: Two people in China have died and another remains critical after falling ill with a strain of bird flu not detected before in humans, the official Chinese news agency Xinhua reported.

item.title: Is China buying up Africa?
item.description: CNN's Ali Velshi explores what billion in Chinese investment in Africa means for the African people.

item.title: 28 killed in coal mine explosion
item.description: A gas explosion Friday night at a northeastern Chinese coal mine killed 28 people, China's state-run Xinhua news agency reported.

item.title: No survivors after Tibet landslide
item.description: Rescuers have yet to find any survivors or bodies Saturday after a landslide that buried 83 workers at a gold mine in the Tibet Autonomous Region, reported Xinhua, the Chinese state-run news agency.
